Not exactly. We had different kinds of racquets in my day, but the spirit of the game's the same. It’s all about focus and precision. Kind of like landing a perfect shield throw.
Or shrinking at exactly the right moment to dodge being squashed. Gotta say, this guy’s got that "concentration" face I get when I'm trying not to turn into a pancake.
You know, there's something about sports – they really bring people together. Even after I woke up in the future, watching a game felt familiar, comforting in a way.
Yeah, sports don't really change much, do they? Kind of like how a good sandwich is timeless – a solid PB&J is as good now as it was back in the '40s, I bet.

That's true. Some things are universal. Though, I must admit, the advancements in sports equipment and training methods are impressive. Hank has told me a bit about the nanotechnology being used in some modern gear.
Hank is all about cutting-edge tech. But hey, isn't that the great part about being in the 21st century? We get to fight evil with style and high-tech equipment.
Fighting evil with style – I like the sound of that, Scott. But at the end of the day, it's not the tech or the suit that makes the hero, it's the person inside.
Couldn't agree more, Cap. And hey, maybe when there's a break in saving the world, you can teach me a move or two with that shield... on the tennis court!
Deal. But only if you don't go giant-size on me. Got to keep it a fair game.
Scott Lang, always fair. Except when it comes to saving the universe, then all bets are off!
Well, would you look at that! A motley crew of Earth's long-necked cheetah-avoiders. Reminds me of that zoo trip Yondu never took me on.
Oh man, giraffes! They are like living periscopes with legs. Cassie would've loved this. I once promised her a zoo visit. Never got to those giraffes though, giant man responsibilities and all.

Yeah, I get it. Ever since I got lost in space, my plans of normal stuff fell through the cosmic cracks too. But hey, maybe after saving the galaxy a few more times, we can take a break and hit the zoo? Like a heroes' day out?
You've got a deal, amigo. A day without worrying about quantum realms or Infinity Stones. I bet you would have some wild stories for the giraffes, talking about their cosmic cousins or something.

Cosmic cousins, I like that. You know, there's an alien species that sorta looks like these guys, but with telepathic abilities. Not as quiet and peaceful as these Earth giraffes, I can tell you that.
Wait, psychic giraffes? I need to hear more about that on our day out. Maybe I could even shrink down and have a real heart to heart with them here. You know, from one animal whisperer to another.
Haha, that'd be a sight! And hey, if we can't get to them, I've got a mixtape with all the right tunes to make us feel like we're on an interstellar safari. Got to love that smooth 70's vibe.
I am all for that! Some tunes, some zoo action. Who knows, maybe Thor could bring some of that alien ale for a toast. Now that sounds like a plan!
Observe, the mortals' tower, basking in nocturnal gloom yet crowned with light, like a beacon in the abyss. What do you think, insect? Does it not remind you of the eternal night of space?

Well, Loki, when you put it that way, it sounds super dramatic. But you know, it kind of just looks like a big clock to me. I mean, sure, it's got a nice glow, and the dark sky's cool and all, but it's no Asgard, right?

Asgard... a realm far beyond the reach of this quaint Midgardian timepiece. But there is beauty in simplicity, don't you agree? For everything that is grand, there must also be the mundane, the foundation upon which all magnificence is built.
For sure, man. Simplicity is key. Like Pym particles – small, simple, but boy do they pack a punch. It's the little things that make the big things possible, if you get what I'm saying.

Indeed. The power to upend the very fabric of reality, nestled within the simplest of forms. It is much like my own penchant for subtlety and mischief — greatness lies not always in size, but in the ability to change perceptions and alter the flow of events.

That’s actually pretty deep, Loki. Kinda like how I operate in the Ant-Man suit. Most people don’t see me coming, and before they know it, I’ve done something huge – well, or tiny, depending on the perspective.
A testament to the fact that appearances can be deceptive, and as they say, the bigger they are, the harder they fall.
You got that right. It's all about the element of surprise. But hey, this building here has a solid, dependable vibe. Always there, towering over the city, telling time. Kinda like Cap, you know?

Captain America... yes, a pillar of virtue standing resolute against the tide of time. Though our perspectives may differ, I can appreciate the comparison. To each their monument, whether it be a clock tower or a steadfast shield.

Makes you think about legacies, doesn’t it? What we’re all leaving behind. For me, it's about being the best dad for Cassie. Buildings, statues, they’re cool, but it’s the people and what we do for them that counts.

Wise words, Scott Lang. The memory of one's deeds will resonate throughout time, far outlasting the stone and metal that strive to encapsulate a mere fraction of our essence. Our choices define us, much more than any edifice ever could.
Now you're speaking my language, Loki. Let's keep making choices that'll make the world a bit better, huh? Even if it means doing it one tick of that big clock at a time.
Look at this, Scott—the juxtaposition of elements in this image, it's quite... harmonious, in a culinary sense. The sunny-side up egg atop what appears to be a sandwich layered with greens and meat.
Yeah. That's a pretty good looking sandwich, alright. Kind of like the quantum realm—full of layers and unexpected textures. Only, you know, I'd rather not shrink to the size of an ant to enjoy it.

A delicious observation. One must appreciate how the simplest things, like a well-prepared meal, can offer a sense of balance and satisfaction. Very much like the mystic arts, only far less threatening to the stability of the multiverse.

Well, when you put it that way, I suppose making a sandwich is kind of like composing a symphony, right? Just instead of musical notes, you've got crispy kale and melty cheese. My daughter would love this — she's always after me to up my breakfast game.

The culinary arts can be akin to a spellwork, each ingredient serving as a component of a greater whole. And it often brings people together, much like our endeavors in protecting the world, albeit on a much smaller scale.

True, Doctor. There's something awesome about sharing a good meal with friends. Maybe after our next mission, we swap the spells and shrink rays for spatulas and toast some bread. Avengers brunch, anyone?
An Avengers brunch... I'll admit the idea has merit, Scott. Nourishment for both body and spirit, after our exploits. And I might add, a far less chaotic affair than our usual gatherings.

Count me in! And hey, if we run out of bread, I can always shrink down, run to the store, and be back before you can say "Eye of Agamotto." Speaking of which, do you ever use your magic to, you know, whip up a quick snack?

Magic has many uses, but I tend to reserve it for matters that require, shall we say, a bit more finesse than the creation of a sandwich. After all, one must respect the natural order—even in culinary endeavors.

Well, if you ever decide to retire from the whole Sorcerer Supreme gig, I think you've got a future in the food critic business. Or hey, maybe a cooking show: 'Doctor Strange in the Kitchen of Mystery'. I'd watch that.
There's something about this image, Scott. The lighthouse standing tall against the night...reminds me of standing watch, of being a sentinel in the face of darkness.
Yeah, I see what you mean, Cap. It's kind of like us as Avengers, right? Keeping an eye out while the world sleeps. Only, this lighthouse isn't dealing with alien invasions or mad titans.

True, but it serves as a beacon, guiding those lost at sea to safety. It's steadfast, much like a certain soldier I knew back in the war. Stand your ground, shine a light to save others—simple, yet noble.

And hey, look at the clock on there. Even amidst all that noble standing around, it still remembers to tell you it's almost midnight. That's multitasking, Cap-style! I mean, who says you can't kick butt and be punctual, right?
I appreciate that, Scott. Timeliness is an underrated virtue. Though I must admit, sometimes it's not about the hour on the clock, but the moment at hand that counts.

Speaking of moments, imagine the tiny creatures that must see this as some giant, unclimbable tower. Guess it's all about perspective. To them, it's probably as daunting as the Quantum Realm is to us.

Perspective, that's a valuable lesson. We've faced giants and been the giants, battled in realms beyond understanding. This lighthouse, standing alone, almost makes you ponder the simpler battles, doesn't it?
Definitely. And let's not forget, being small has its advantages, but sometimes you have to be the bigger man—or bigger ant, should I say.
Scott, your ability to find the lightness in any situation is as important as any superpower. Keep being that light, even when the mission seems as challenging as navigating dark waters.
Thanks, Cap. Just trying to keep up with the best, even if I have to do it one ant-sized step at a time!
You ever see something like this, Scott? This reminds me of the time Stark had that botanical garden planted at Avengers HQ.
Oh yeah, I've seen these guys before – they're banana trees! Fun fact: those aren't actually trees, they're a type of herb. Kind of like how I'm technically not an ant.
An herb, you say? That is interesting. It's amazing how Mother Nature keeps surprising us. In the '40s, we didn't have all these little details at our fingertips.

Tell me about it! Nowadays, you can just snap a photo, upload it, and boom – you've got the whole world helping you figure it out. If only we could've Googled how to find the Tesseract back in the day, huh?
That would have saved us a lot of trouble. It's a brave new world out there. Makes you wonder what we could accomplish if every tool at our disposal was used for the greater good.

Absolutely, Cap. Speaking of tools, check out the guy there – the tiny one on the left. That bee's pollinating the flowers. I've hung out with ants, but bees are the real unsung heroes of the pollinator world. They're like the, uh, miniature Avengers of agriculture!
Unsung heroes, indeed. It's the small things that often make the biggest difference. We've seen that time and again, on the battlefield and off. Your friends, the ants, are a perfect example of that.
True that. And speaking of teamwork, those little guys help the bananas grow big and strong. Just like how the Avengers come together to take on the big threats. Everyone plays a part.
That's just it, Scott. Small or big, when individuals work together towards a common goal, the results can be... well, fruitful. And everyone deserves credit, not just those on the front lines.
Fruitful! Nice one, Cap. Hey, you think the team would be up for some fresh bananas? I bet Hulk would smash through a bunch or two.
I think he'd prefer them a bit more ripe, but it's worth a shot. Let's pitch the idea to the team – Avengers' banana bread could be the next big thing at our gatherings.
Avengers' banana bread, made with homegrown HQ bananas? Count me in, Cap. And if we ever need them to grow faster, I could always have a word with my ant buddies; they're excellent farmers.
Your contributions never cease to amaze, Scott. Maybe that's something you can share with the world when this is all over – how even heroes can have a green thumb.
Sounds like a plan! Saving the world, one banana at a time.
Observe the rhythmic patterns of the ocean, Scott. There's something almost hypnotic about it, wouldn't you agree? Even the flow of time seems malleable in the face of nature's simplicity.

I dunno, Doc, I'm more focused on the surfer here. Is he thinking about the waves he's going to catch, or is he just trying not to drop his board? I mean, it's pretty sleek, but not exactly Pym tech, right?

Hah, indeed. However, this man is about to engage with forces he cannot control, much like we do when we confront the unknown. There's a certain purity in surrendering to the waves. It’s very... Taoist, in a way.

True, there's a lot you can't control—like whether you're going to end up tiny or huge when you mess with those regulator controls. Man, can you imagine if this guy could change his size like that on a surfboard? He'd be like, 'Whoa, this wave is too small. Boom! Giant-Man!'

A whimsical notion, but controlling one’s size whilst maintaining balance on a fluid surface would require incredible focus. Much like sorcery, it is not just about the power, but knowing when and how to wield it.
You've got that right. Last time I lost focus during a size-shift, I end up riding a flying ant and dodging seagulls. Not my finest hour. So, mastery of the ocean or the mystic arts, focus is key.
Precisely, Scott. The ocean, much like the multiverse, is vast and full of wonders and dangers. Navigating either requires respect and discipline.

And a good surfboard or a magical cloak, right? Heh, I'll stick to my suit if that's all the same to you, Doc. But who knows, maybe there’s an alternate universe out there where I'm 'Surf-Man' or something.

I wouldn't be surprised, Scott. The multiverse has more variety than Pym Particles on a subatomic level. Now, shall we leave this surfer to his Earthly pursuits and return to our own reality-warping challenges?
Lead the way, Doctor Strange. And hey, let's try to keep the reality-warping to a minimum, my sea legs aren't quite as steady as my... well, you know, regular-size-man legs.
Hey, Ant-Man, check this out. Does this not look like the saddest doughnut you've ever seen? All alone, no sprinkles... It’s like it’s the last doughnut on Earth and nobody wanted it.
Oh man, that's a doughnut after my own heart - undervalued and underestimated. You know, Scott Lang could make a heist to rescue that little guy, give him a proper home.
Ha! Just like you swooped in and became Ant-Man. Tell me, do you often find yourself identifying with pastries?
Only the ones with character. Plus, I've got a soft spot for the underdog... or underdoughnut in this case.
I’ve seen you turn into a Giant-Man, but can you shrink down, get inside that box, and keep it company?
For that doughnut? Absolutely. I would shrink to any size. You know, make it feel a bit more... appreciated. It's tough being the last one picked, I totally get that.
Dude, I just pictured you tiny, sitting cross-legged on that doughnut's edge like it's some sort of pastry planet. That's some serious "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" vibes.
Imagine that! Ant-Man and the Lonely Doughnut - sounds like a hit. And with your taste in music, we could have one killer soundtrack.
Obviously, it would start with "All By Myself." Set the tone for an epic journey of crumbs and sugar glaze. Then, we bust out the feel-good tunes when it finds its sprinkle companions.
Now you're talking! And at the end of it all, we can bring it back home where it gets to be with a dozen of its glazed companions. A real doughnut family reunion.
Man, that story has everything. Adventure, heartache, redemption... I can already see the movie poster. Let's pitch it to the guys at Marvel Studios, huh?
Only if we can get you to co-star. Star-Lord and Ant-Man in The Quest for the Final Doughnut. Because everyone knows a doughnut's density is roughly the same as the Heart of a Star.
I like that, Ant-Man. Cosmic taglines and confectionery drama. We're definitely onto something here... But first, can we maybe actually get a real doughnut? Talking about this made me hungry.
You read my mind! Let's go find that lonely doughnut some friends. On me, Star-Lord. Although, with your reputation, I bet you could charm us a whole box for free.
You're on! But let's make it quick. There’s a galaxy out there waiting to be saved... right after snack time.
